p.em: what does it mean for traditional racial categories to be "valid?"

div.p: I disagree this is the question that needs answered. The better question is, are they useful? In what ways are they useful? What do they actually tell us that we need to know? I don't think they're that useful as more than a historical interest point.

I think this is where the progressive side trips on its face; it tries to have its race-cake and eat it too: "oh they don't really exist but also they're super important and we're going to create legislation to protect people and give them stuff based on this thing that totally doesn't exist."

blockquote.p: 10% of self-IDed African-Americans can trace most of their ancestry to Europe.

div.p: Well... this would be one failure point, but isn't really a death knell for the definition. African-Americans (and really, not even AA, but specifically Black people) are one of the more admixed groups for the obvious historical reasons, but they still comprise a quite small percent of the world population. Biology is messy, and that it works for 95% but not 5% is kind of a stupid reason to throw something out if there's not a better replacement (hint: we don't have one yet) (see also gender being not quite binary but HIGHLY bimodal).

The wiki page on human genetic clusters is pretty good. K is the number of groupings, and k=5 (Africa, Eurasia (Europe, Middle East, and Central/South Asia), East Asia, Oceania, and the Americas ) might be the most common because it's the most useful. Take note there: oceans and mountains. Beyond this the split-offs get smaller and smaller, and less informative. The Kalash people might be most well-known for splitting off at K=7 for a population that's hardly a few tens of thousands, and they're more interesting than the K=6 tribes for political reasons. K=6 actually splits off an even smaller group, as it separates the Americas into "two Brazilian tribes of less than 2,000 people total" and "every other indigenous American."

p.strong: Racial identities match up with genetic ancestry.
Racial identities correspond to clusters of human genetic variation

div.p: I don't think there's as much daylight here as you seem to think. You can only determine ancestry by variation. If there was no variation, we'd all be clones. Racial identities (except for 10% of Black people, or less than 1/10 of 1% of the world population) line up quite close to the ancestry genetic clustering. Race is different than ethnicity, though, and both are distinct from culture (well... sort of).

blockquote.p: If this is true, then can't we split humans into hundreds, if not thousands, of races?

div.p: It also depends on what genetic information you're looking at. Autosomal ancestry markers: K=5 reigns king. Y-haplogroups, however, are much more varied. The wiki pages are considerably less informative (or rather, considerably more broken-up because it is finer-grained) and will break up much smaller groups.

If you wanted to make a genetic "race versus ethnicity" distinction, this would be the way to do it. Autosomal info can get you "Eurasian" but Y haplogroups will get you "Kosovo Albanian" or distinguishing almost 20 kinds of Arab.

blockquote.p: Why use "race," a term with heavy historical baggage and a widely-recognized popular meaning, to refer to genetic clusters when you could use "population" or "group" instead?

div.p: Because most people are uneducated, and they stick with the term that's been used for decades if not centuries. Academics will use "populations" for this reason; good luck getting it into the popular discourse especially as long as people continue to use race for other reasons (terms like racist, employment quotas, scholarships, etc).
